content:
Father abandons his daughter in forest and leaves axes tied
so that they move in wind.

Daughter thinks
he is cutting wood. *Roberts 137.

(Cf. †T520.) *Nutt FLR
IV 1ff., Gaster Thespis 255; Greek: Grote I 103; Jewish: Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys.

(Cf. †S12.2.1, †T640.)
*Encyc. Religion Ethics s.v. “Abandonment and
exposure”; *Nutt FLR IV 1ff.; Frazer Apollodorus I 252 n. 2; Aarne FFC XXIII
63; *Hertel Zs. f. Vksk. XIX 83ff., 91. -- Irish myth: *Cross; Icelandic:
*Boberg; Italian Novella: Rotunda; India: *Thompson-Balys.
child:
(Cf. †T410.) *Type 933; Köhler-Bolte Zs. f.
Vksk. VI 173 (to Gonzenbach No. 85); *Baum PMLA XXXI 562 n. 59; Krappe
Neuphilologische Mitteilungen XXXIV (1933) 11--22; Irish myth: *Cross;
Icelandic: Boberg.

Woman abandons baby boy (of which she was artificially
impregnated) in forest.

Parents successively bury alive their sons who mention
something about smith’s, potter‘s, washerman’s, and tom-tom beater‘s trade, but
keep fifth child who says something about being future king.

content: Exposure of child in boat (floating chest).
Child‘s ankles pierced before exposing him.
N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 91.

Children abandoned (driven forth, exposed) by hostile
relative.

*Roberts 128; Irish myth:
*Cross; Spanish: Espinosa II No. 114, Espinosa Jr. No. 140.
child: Orphaned boy deprived of his inheritance by relatives.

Spanish: Espinosa II Nos. 107f., 154, Espinosa Jr. Nos.
120--123.
Father who wanted son exposes (murders) daughter.

Irish myth: *Cross; Greek: Fox 56 (Atalanta); India:
*Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries’s list No. 203.
Father casts daughter forth when she will not marry him.

(Cf. †T411.1.) *Type
510B; BP II 45; Cox passim; Krappe Zeitschrift für englische Philologie XLIX
361--69; Spanish: Espinosa II Nos. 99--103.

Exposure in jungle for refusing to marry according to
father‘s wishes.

Father condemns daughter to death because he believes her
unchaste.

Type 883A; India:
Thompson-Balys; Africa (Somali): Kirk FL XV 319ff. No. 3, Reinisch Die
Saho-Sprache (Wien, 1889) I 76ff. No. 3.

Princess humiliated by father after she has married loathly
bridegroom.
Boy turned out of doors by father.
King, jealous of son, banishes him and his wife.
Mother exposes child (for fear of jealous co-wife).
Jealous co-wife demands murder of woman‘s children.
Jealous concubine plots against real wife’s daughter.

Banishment (death) of stepchildren demanded as cure for
feigned illness.
Evil stepmother orders stepdaughter to be killed.

Stepmother irritates two stepsons so that one kills the
other.

Jealous mother-in-law and sisters cast woman’s children
forth.

Evil stepmother works stepdaughter to death in absence of
merchant husband.

content:
Parents trick children into going on hunt, and then abandon
them in forest.

child:
Eskimo (Greenland):
Rasmussen I 374, (Mackenzie Area): Jenness 34a; N. A. Indian (Zuñi): Benedict
II 335; Africa (Wachaga): Gutmann 142.

content: India: Thompson-Balys; Indonesia: DeVries‘s list No. 205.
Child cast out because of his stupidity.
child: Father wants to kill son because of foolish boasting.

Baby ordered killed because it pulls beard of father
(raja).
Half-wit abandoned because of his tricks.

content: Mother induced by rival to kill her children.
Tokens of royalty (nobility) left with exposed child.

(Cf. †H80.) *Penzer VII
81 n. 1; Irish myth: Cross; English: Wells 134 (Sir Degare), 126 (Lai Le
Freine); Greek: Fox 71.
child:
Child exposed with twelve years’ supply of food and
attendants.

content: Abandoned children return and kill parents.
N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 89.
Mother sells her child to heathen sailors.
Starving parents come to abandoned child for food.

Jewish: *Neuman (Joseph); Sulka of New Britain: Dixon 132
n. 2; N. A. Indian: *Thompson Tales 349 n. 255.
Children enticed into grain pot and imprisoned.

child:
Exposure given up on account of newborn son‘s protesting
stanza.

content: Pregnant woman ordered by husband to kill child to be born.
Son killed at instigation of lover.
child: Woman asks suitor to kill the child of his first wife.

content: Queen hides her child and accuses wolf of eating it.

child: Child exposed so as to avoid death decree.

content:
When she is refused entrance to house, she makes complaint
in a song and brothers bring her clothes. Lithuanian: Balys Index No. 883C*.
Children left at home seek exposed brothers and sisters.
Exposed child carried off by wild beast.

Exposed infant reared at strange king’s court (Joseph,
Oedipus).

*Type 931; Irish myth: *Cross;
Jewish: Neuman, bin Gorion Born Judas@2 I 165, 372; India: Thompson-Balys.
child: Abandoned child adopted and found by queen.

Travelers find exposed baby girl and take her to emperor‘s
court.

content: Abandoned child reared by supernatural beings.
child: Deity nurtures and rears abandoned child.
Exposed children miraculously fed by angels.

content:
(Cf. †B535.) Missouri
French: Carrière; India: *Thompson-Balys; S. A. Indian (Sherenti): Lowe BBAE
CXLIII (1) 515; West Indies: Flowers 576.
child:
Animal preserves fire for abandoned children in a clam
shell.

content: Abandoned child cared for by mother secretly.
child:
Abandoned child made over to its own mother (sister) acting
as wet nurse.

Abandoned child cared for by grandmother (aunt, foster
mother).

Irish: *Cross, MacCulloch Celtic
167; N. A. Indian (California): Gayton and Newman 91.

(Cf. †R131.3.) Irish
myth: Cross; Greek: Grote I 241, 263; Buddhist myth: Malalasekera I 458.

Abandoned princess, brought up by herdsmen, becomes wife of
king.

Irish myth: *Cross; Buddhist myth:
Malalasekera I 378.
Infant condemned to death saved by a smile.
Child driven out (exposed) brought up in secret.

content:
*Dixon 130, 132 n. 2, 136 nn. 10, 11; Greek: Grote I 854;
India: *Thompson-Balys.
Bird carries food from deserted child to starving parents.

Old woman’s maledictions inform abandoned hero of his
parentage and future.

He has knocked her
over (broken pots). *Cosquin Contes indiens 398.
Tree feeds abandoned children with its sap.
